Topic.Title: A lie, other lies, and more lies . . .

Message.Msg: NASDAQ: I'm not a clown. I've down more than 2X 3 years in a row and am tracking for a 4th. I'm old school. Economic fundamental with a little strategic insight to understand how things might evolve and the implications of those scenarios for the company in question. Amazon is a great company. It's valuation is an absurd scam. There is NOTHING about sales taxes increasing that is good for AMZN. Had it been better for AMZN, it would have aggressively expanded to the state level even before, since losing the tax benefit would have been an advantage. Anyone thinking logically understands that it is a net negative for AMZN. What it is trying to do is to prevent smaller upstart competitors from having the same advantage against it that it enjoyed against classic bricks and mortar retail. I'm just trying to help retail longs understand the TRUE underlying fundamental dynamics. I don't care about you. I care about real retail investors and want to protect them (as I managed to do for many Green Mountain longs who trimmed around 100 after all of my posts -- there are many on that board still grateful to me for it...) from the misinformation. Amazon's capital intensity is increasing. Inventory turns decreasing and necessarily will continue to as it increases the number of locations at which inventory is held. The value proposition of inventory closer to the consumer is questionable. The increase is price paid for many consumers who WILL have to pay tax in not under question. I could go on, but feel no need. As I said, I will be here for the ride down...

Topic.Title: If the world were valued like AMZN...

Message.Msg: Nasdaq, I have read your posts on this MB for over a year, for the most part you have done very well, kudos to you. But my question to you, that is if you really have a position and are not getting paid by the post, at what point to you start to take some off the table? If you are a sane investor you have to see the valuation issue at hand? Nothing wrong with riding a hot hand but do have a game plan to ease out of this long position? Or are you going to be like some of the people I know that rode SUNW, AOL and EBAY all the way down in 2000. - Pj

Message.Msg: That was I've done not down... Rather significant difference... Look at my history. Nailed NFLX based upon competitive dynamics and the realization that its DVD business had advantaged economics but streaming wouldn't. Nailed GMCR as a company that would suffer huge margin hits as product mix shifted proprietary to contract. There's more (CMG and LULU, but the full thesis has yet to play out). I can't tell you how often I see people crowing about their wisdom just at the point of reversal. I'm sure you have seen it as well. Not saying it will happen, but that kind of behavior is often a sign of an impending reversal. Don't be blind to the possibility.

Message.Title: Machines Starting to Exit AMZN
Message.Msg: If ever there was a doubt that AMZN the stock is run by dark pools and hedge fund HFT machines, all you have to do is look at AMZN's trading behavior. Over 80% of the volume in AMZN is between machines. And as such, AMZN often displays little true price discovery, bouncing wildly between .50 and $1.00 with wide bid/offers in between. But the machines appear to be exiting, especially after last weeks attempt to break the old highs. Except they didn't. A classic failure at the top, even with AAPL the magnificent pushing new highs. Clear divergence. Today at the close, AMZN displayed remarkable price discovery. Although volume is light, characteristic of a market top, transactions were occurring at tight bid offer spreads. Selling occurred all day, but at orderly levels. A sign that the machines took the day off. Or maybe more. At the close, the machines got involved just for a moment. AMZN was trading tightly between 239.10 and 239.25. Then, without any real transactions, the close prints 239.55 -.82. A sign the machines want the stock as high as possible in the morning, so they can start distributing again. Once the light volume is absorbed, AMZN will start to have gap down days. Then everybody will really start scratching their heads.

Topic.Title: THANK YOU AGAIN SYBIL!! EVERYTHING YOU TOUCH SHORT IS ROCKING!!

Message.Msg: Of course. But, I'm not viewing as an earnings play. I'm looking at the strategic game board and seeing trouble for CRM. The entire OpenStack initiative (consortium to eliminate AMZN's switching cost /lock in to AWS) is also providing fodder for RackSpace and folks like that to layer in open source / portability for CRM. I see RackSpace acquiring someone like SugarCRM and scaling the offering to its much broader base. More price / margin pressure for CRM and elimination of lock in effect (most CRM systems just aren't that different because they all target the same business processes...). It is a small position for me, but like GMCR is could pay off big. FYI PJ, I took 40% of my GMCR position off at the close today. I pocketed $15K net of original investment and everything I have left is the houses money, so no matter what I will have made out well there. I have no intention of selling anything more as I believe it will see $40 (in which case I'll make another $60K or so) within 12 months UNLESS we have a meltdown, in which case I'll make a killing elsewhere (here?).
